stem: A 12-year-old child with Sickle Cell Disease is hospitalized for a vaso-occlusive crisis. Based on the documentation in the Respiratory & Pain Flowsheet, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Pediatric client with SCD admitted 24 hours ago for pain.
Background: History of multiple crises. Receiving IV fluids and morphine.
Assessment: Client reports new onset of chest pain and a cough. Respiratory rate has increased.
Recommendation: Rule out pulmonary infarctions.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 102/60, HR 118, RR 26, SpO2 89% on RA (Previously 97%).

actionOptions.text: Administer humidified oxygen to maintain SpO2 > 94%
Encourage use of the incentive spirometer every hour
Administer Aspirin to prevent further platelet aggregation
Apply cold compresses to the chest for pain relief

parameterOptions.text: Chest X-ray findings (Check for new infiltrates)

rationale.correct: Acute Chest Syndrome (ACS) (c2) is a life-threatening complication of SCD characterized by a new pulmonary infiltrate on X-ray, chest pain, fever, and respiratory distress. Priority actions are to support oxygenation (a1) and prevent further atelectasis/infarction through incentive spirometry (a2). Key parameters include oxygen saturation (p1) and radiological confirmation of infiltrates (p2).
clinicalPearls: ACS is the leading cause of death in Sickle Cell Disease.
Incentive spirometry is CRITICAL; it helps prevent the crisis from spreading through the lungs.
NEVER apply cold to an SCD client; it causes vasoconstriction and worsens the sickling.

questionTrap.trap: Applying ice packs for chest pain in a sickle cell patient.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Warmth promotes blood flow; cold stops it. Cold compresses are ALWAYS contraindicated in SCD vaso-occlusive events.

mnemonic.title: ACS Cues
mnemonic.expansion: C-Chest pain. H-High fever. E-Exit sounds (Crackles). S-Saturation drop. T-Tachypnea.
